security_module.name: Enable the Audit Subsystem
security_module.description: Enables the audit subsystem to record security-relevant events occurring on your system.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Audit Log Rotation
security_module.description: Configure the system to rotate audit logs on a daily basis.

security_module.name: Audit Rules
security_module.description: Configures the Linux audit subsystem to record relevant security events such as file access, file deletions, login, logout, session initiations, discretionary access control changes, and administrative actions.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Audit Rules (Solaris)
security_module.description: Configures the Solais audit subsystem to record relevant security events such as file access, file deletions, login, logout, session initiations, discretionary access control changes, and administrative actions.

security_module.name: Enable vsftpd Additional Logging
security_module.description: Configures Vsftpd daemon to log all FTP requests and responses.

security_module.name: Enable Auditing For All Processes
security_module.description: Require the 'audit=1' flag as a kernel option. This allows processes that start before auditd to be audited.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: System Accounting
security_module.description: Enables system accounting to gather system usage such as CPU utilization and Disk I/O.

security_module.name: SELinux Must Not Be Disabled
security_module.description: Require the 'selinux=0' flag not be present as a kernel option. This flag would prevent SELinux from being effective as a security feature.

security_module.name: Secure Authpriv Logging
security_module.description: Secures authpriv logging so that security-related logging information is sent to /var/log/secure, which is readable only by the superuser.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Cron Logging
security_module.description: Configures cron(8) logging so that cron-related logging information is sent to /var/log/cron, which is readable only by the superuser.

security_module.name: Disable CDE ToolTalk Database Server
security_module.description: Disables the Local CDE ToolTalk Database Server. The ToolTalk service enables independent CDE desktop applications to communicate with each other without having direct knowledge of each other.

security_module.name: MySQL - Disable command history
security_module.description: Disables the MySQL command history by setting the MYSQL_HISTFILE environment variable to "" for all login sessions.

security_module.name: Restrict the CDE Subprocess Control Service
security_module.description: Add the CDE Subprocess Control Service (dtspcd) daemon's port (tcp/6112) to the privileged port list. This prevents users from opening up the service.

security_module.name: Create ftpusers File
security_module.description: Creates the files /etc/ftpusers, /etc/ftpd/ftpusers, or /etc/vsftpd.ftpusers if they do not exist. It then adds the root user and all the system users to these files. These files contain the usernames of users who are NOT allowed to use FTP on the system. If these files already exist, this module will leave existing entries but add missing system accounts.

security_module.name: Disable FTP (gssftp)
security_module.description: Disables gssftp, which is a FTP server provided with the Kerberos Workstation package.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable FTP (vsftpd)
security_module.description: Disables vsftpd, which is a FTP server.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable File Sharing Networks
security_module.description:
Peer-to-peer transfer services allow for the anonymous transfer of files. If not configured correctly, your system files may become writable. This module will disable the executables and connection daemons for most of the file sharing networks available to Linux.
This module searches for the following executables in most standard directories: apollon, bittorrent, bittorrent-console, bittorrent-curses, giftd, gift-gnutella, gift-setup, gtk-gnutella, LimeWire.jar, mlbt, mldc, mldonkey, mlgnut, mlslsk, nap, napping, and qtella. If found, the permissions will be set to zeros.

security_module.name: Disable Fspd
security_module.description: Disable the fspd daemon. If fspd is installed, this module will remove all permissions from the executable so it cannot be used.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Instant Messenger Client (gaim)
security_module.description: Disables the GAIM and Pidgin instant messenger client. If the GAIM or Pidgin package is installed, this module will remove all permissions from /usr/bin/gaim and /usr/bin/pidgin. On Solaris systems, this module will look in /usr/local/bin.

security_module.name: Disable NFS Client
security_module.description: Disables the NFS client. The NFS is a file system exported by remote servers. This module prevents the client from sharing network files remotely.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5
Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5
Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable NFS Server
security_module.description: Disables the NFS server. The NFS is a file system exported by remote servers. This module prevents the server from sharing network files remotely.

security_module.name: Disable NetFS
security_module.description: Disables the NetFS functionality, which encapsulates NFS, Novell Netware, and Windows file sharing services.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable rpc.ugidd
security_module.description: rpc.ugidd is available for many Linux distributions. It performs user and group identification matching jobs for NFS servers.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable SMB
security_module.description: Disables SMB, which is the Windows file sharing protocol. The SMB server provides file and print services to Windows-based systems.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable TFTP
security_module.description: Disables TFTP, which is typically used for network booting of diskless workstations, X-terminals, and other remote devices.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable UUCP
security_module.description: Disables the Unix-to-Unix Copy (UUCP) service. This is a utillity and protocol that enables one computer to send files to another computer over a direct serial connection or via modems and the telephone system.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Instant Messenger Client (Yahoo!)
security_module.description: Disables the Yahoo! instant messenger client. If the "ymessenger" package is installed, this module will remove all permissions from /usr/bin/ymessenger so it cannot be used.

security_module.name: Set FTP Umask (gssftp)
security_module.description: Sets the default umask on the GSS FTP Server. This umask setting is 077 and it affects files uploaded by users. This is to prevent other users from reading or writing to other user files.

security_module.name: Remove ftp Account
security_module.description: Remove FTP Account

security_module.name: Remove SMB Guest Authentication
security_module.description: Disables support for guest access to Samba shares and printers.

security_module.name: SMB Configuration
security_module.description: Checks for recommended global Samba configuration settings.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5
Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5
Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5
Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5
Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Set TFTP Startup Directory
security_module.description: Sets the TFTP startup directory to /tftpboot for incoming connections.

security_module.name: Check for separate /home file system
security_module.description: The /home file system must be its own separate partion or logical volume.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Check for separate /tmp file system
security_module.description: The /tmp file system must be its own separate partion or logical volume.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Check for separate /var file system
security_module.description: The /var file system must be its own separate partion or logical volume.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Check for separate /var/log file system
security_module.description: The /var/log file system must be its own separate partion or logical volume.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Check for separate /var/log/audit file system
security_module.description: The /var/log/audit file system must be its own separate partion or logical volume.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Check Kernel for XD/NX Support
security_module.description: Scan only module, which checks the running to kernel to see if it supports Execute Disable (XD) or No Execute (NX). Later 32-bit processors in the x86 family support the ability to prevent code execution on a per memory page basis.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Create Login Banner
security_module.description: Displays a warning banner during login which may assist in prosecuting unauthorized system use.

option.name: loginBanner
option.description: Login banner text for motd(5) and issue(5).
option.helpText: Required text for login banner

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Create Login FTP Banner
security_module.description: Displays a warning banner during login which may assist in prosecuting unauthorized system use.

option.name: ftpLoginBanner
option.description: Login banner text for FTP sessions.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Create Pre-Login GUI Banner
security_module.description: Displays a short text message before GUI login. Can be used to briefly describe the system, or announce that a 'Consent to Monitor' banner must be agreed to before login will complete.

option.name: preLoginBanner
option.description: Explicit text for pre login message.
option.helpText: Desired text for the prelogin banner. This message should be short, no more than a sentence or two. Anything longer should be in either the 'Create Login GUI Banner' or 'Create Pre-Sessions GUI Banner' module.
option.default: All users will be required to read and accept a 'Consent to Monitor' statement before being allowed to login. The response will be logged.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Create Pre-Session GUI Banner
security_module.description: Displays a warning banner during GUI login which may assist in prosecuting unauthorized system use. This banner is displayed after the user has authenticated, but before the desktop is presented

option.name: requireAssent
option.helpText: Select between using a Consent Banner (with the username and answer logged), or simply use an Informative banner.

option.name: bannerSrc
option.helpText: Select the source of the test, either the 'Message of the Day' file (/etc/motd) or from the 'Manual Banner Text' field.

option.name: bannerText
option.helpText: Text for the Banner if different from /etc/motd

option.name: formatBanner
option.helpText: Allow reformatting the text into 'paragraphs', with line breaks inserted into appropriate places. All single newlines will be converted to two spaces. Two newlines will be treated as an explicit paragraph boundary.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Ctrl-Alt-Del
security_module.description: Disables the Ctrl+Alt+Del reboot key sequence to prevent some accidental system reboots in mixed OS environments where Ctrl+Alt+Del is commonly used to initiate a login. The use of Ctrl+Alt+Del is an easy way for an attacker who has physical access to the system to circumvent security measures of the system.

security_module.name: Disable Bluetooth Kernel Modules
security_module.description: Prevent kernel from loading Bluetooth modules.

option.name: requiredLines
option.description: Required lines to disable Bluetooth kernel module(s)
option.default: alias net-pf-31 off alias bluetooth off install bluetooth /bin/true

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Core Dumps
security_module.description: Disables core dumps. Core dumps can consume considerable amounts of disk space and could contain sensitive data. It is recommended that you disable core dumps if they are not needed.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable CUPS Printer Browsing
security_module.description: Disables printer browsing from the Common UNIX Printing System (CUPS). If enabled, the machine will both broadcast a list of all printers on this system as well as listen to any other such broadcasts.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable GNOME Automounting
security_module.description: Prevent the GNOME desktop environment from automatically mounting devices and removable media (such as DVDs, CDs, and USB flash drives) whenever they are inserted into the system.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable IPv6 Kernel Module
security_module.description: Prevent kernel from loading IPv6 kernel module.

option.name: requiredLines
option.description: Required lines to disable Firewire kernel module(s)
option.default: alias ipv6 off alias net-pf-10 off

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Interactive Boot
security_module.description: Disables interactive system startups, which prevents the operator from selecting which set of system services will be started on boot.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Support for Firewire
security_module.description: Prevent kernel from loading the Firewire (IEEE1394) protocol module.

option.name: requiredLines
option.description: Required lines to disable Firewire kernel module(s)

security_module.name: Disable Support for DCCP
security_module.description: Prevent kernel from loading the Datagram Congestion Control Protocol (DCCP) module.

option.name: requiredLines
option.description: Required lines to disable Firewire kernel module(s)

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Support for RDS
security_module.description: Prevent kernel from loading the Reliable Datagram Sockets (RDS) protocol module.

option.name: requiredLines
option.description: Required lines to disable Firewire kernel module(s)

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Support for SCTP
security_module.description: Prevent kernel from loading the Stream Control Transmission Protocol (SCTP) module.

option.name: requiredLines
option.description: Required lines to disable Firewire kernel module(s)

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Support for TIPC
security_module.description: Prevent kernel from loading the Transparent Inter-Process Communication (TIPC) protocol module.

option.name: requiredLines
option.description: Required lines to disable Firewire kernel module(s)

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Mounting of Uncommon Filesystem Types
security_module.description: Prevent kernel from loading modules for uncommon file system.

option.name: requiredLines
option.description: Required lines to disable Firewire kernel module(s)
option.default: install cramfs /bin/true install freevxfs /bin/true install jffs2 /bin/true install hfsplus /bin/true install squashfs /bin/true install udf /bin/true

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Support for USB Storage devices
security_module.description: Prevent kernel from loading the USB Storage kernel module.

option.name: requiredLines
option.description: Required lines to disable Firewire kernel module(s)

security_module.name: Disable SUID Core Dumps
security_module.description: Prevent Set-UID programs from writing a core dump file if the program is terminated due abnormally.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable USB and PCMCIA Devices
security_module.description: Disables USB and PCMCIA ports on the system. USB and PCMCIA ports are used to attach PCMCIA cards, USB drives, and memory devices.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Zeroconf Networking
security_module.description: Disables 'Zeroconf' networking to prevent a system from assigning itself an IP address and engage in IP communication without a statically-assigned address or DHCP server. Automatic address assignment via Zeroconf is not recommended.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Enable ExecShield Kernel Module
security_module.description: Red Hat's ExecShield comprises a number of kernel features to provide protection against buffer overflows. These features include random placement of the stack and other memory regions, prevention of execution in memory that should only hold data, and special handling of text buffers.

option.name: requiredLines
option.description: Required settings for /etc/sysconf.conf, one per line <param> = <valuegt;

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Enable Stack Protection
security_module.description: Enables the stack to be marked as nonexecutable, which helps make buffer-overflow attacks more difficult. This module is not applicable to Linux-based systems.

security_module.name: Exec shell startups in /etc/profile.d
security_module.description: Under Solaris, ensure that files in /etc/profile.d are executed by a login shell. N/A for Linux, as these are executed by default

security_module.name: Use NODEV Option for Non-root Partitions
security_module.description: Places the nodev option on non-root partitions, which prevents users from mounting unauthorized devices on partitions that should not contain devices. There should be no need to mount devices on any partition other than /dev.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Use NOSUID and NODEV for Removable Media
security_module.description: Places the nodev and nosuid options on removable media partitions, which prevents users from bringing set-UID programs into the system via CD-ROMs and floppy disks.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Remove Gopher User Account
security_module.description: Disables gopher user accounts. As a general precaution, it is recommended that you remove default system accounts that are not used or needed. The more accounts that are present on the system the more opportunities an attacker has to gain access or information about your system.

security_module.name: GRUB Boot Single Image
security_module.description: This module ensures that there is at most one bootable definition in a GRUB config file. If not, all images except the default image are removed.

security_module.name: Password Protect GRUB
security_module.description: This module has been retired and has been replaced by the 'Require GRUB Password' module. This module will still reverse previous changes (undo), however it will only scan from this point on. It is recommended that you remove this modoule from your profile and use the new module.

security_module.name: Remove Halt User Account
security_module.description: Removes halt user account. As a general precaution, default system accounts that are not used or needed should be removed. The more accounts that are present on the system the more opportunities an attacker has to gain access or information about your system.

security_module.name: Use NOSUID on User Filesystems
security_module.description: Places the nosuid option on user filesystems, which prevents users from bringing set-UID programs into the system.

security_module.name: Restrict Remote X Clients
security_module.description: Restricts remote X clients. The X servers listen on TCP port 6000 for messages from remote clients. However, the authentication protocol is relatively unsecure and an attacker who is able to gain unauthorized access to the local X server can compromise the system. Adding the "-nolisten tcp" argument to the server disables this functionality.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Remove Games User Account
security_module.description: Removes "games" system account.

security_module.name: Remove News User Account
security_module.description: Removes "news" system account.

security_module.name: Require GRUB Password
security_module.description: This scan-only module ensures the GRand Unified Bootloader (GRUB) is password protected. This ensures kernel parameters cannot be changed at boot time without the correct password.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Restrict At and Cron
security_module.description: Restricts the use of the at(1) and crontab(1) commands to a list of specified users.

security_module.name: Ensure SELinux is Properly Enabled
security_module.description: This module sets the mode(disabled, enabled, permissive) and policy(targeted, strict, mls) for SELinux.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5
Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Secure Netrc Files
security_module.description: Restricts .netrc file permissions to owner read and write access, which prevents others from gaining access to this information. The .netrc files are used for remote login without interaction. This is achieved through storing an unencrypted password in the file. If used, these files should be protected from all other users.

security_module.name: Remove Shutdown User Account
security_module.description: Removes shutdown system account so that only a root login can shut down the system. As a general precaution, it is recommended that you remove this system account. The more accounts that are present on the system the more opportunities an attacker has to gain access or information about your system.

security_module.name: SSHD Logging Level
security_module.description: Set Secure Shell Server's logging level

security_module.name: SSHD Maximum Authentication Attempts
security_module.description: Set Secure Shell Server's maximum authentication attempts permitted per connection.

option.name: sshdMaxAuthTries
option.description: Maximum number of authentication attempts permitted per connection.

security_module.name: SSHD Set Idle Timeout Interval for User Logins
security_module.description: Set Secure Shell Server's idle timeout interval. After this interval has passed, the idle user will be automatically logged out.

option.name: sshdIdleTimeout
option.description: Number of seconds a shell can be idle before the system automatically terminates the session.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Remove Sync User Account
security_module.description: Removes sync user account. As a general precaution, default system accounts that are not used or needed should be removed. The more accounts that are present on the system the more opportunities an attacker has to gain access or information about your system.

security_module.name: Remove Telnet Service Banner
security_module.description: Removes the telnet service banner. On Solaris systems, the standard warning banner is displayed and then the telnet service banner is displayed, which often contains the operating system version.

security_module.name: User Mountable Media
security_module.description: Restricts the use of removable media drives. User-mountable media is a security risk. Allowing users to mount and access data from removable media drives makes it easier for malicious programs and data to be imported onto the network or for data to be removed from the server.

security_module.name: Disable Mail (Cyrus mail server)
security_module.description: Disables Cyrus, which is a mail server that provides IMAP, POP3, and KPOP support. IMAPS/POP3S/NNTPS support (IMAP/POP3/NNTP encrypted using SSL) can be used for security.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Mail (Dovecot mail server)
security_module.description: Disables Dovecot, which is a mail server written primarily with security in mind. It provides IMAP and POP3 support. The IMAPS and POP3S support (IMAP and POP3 encrypted using SSL) can be used for security.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Sendmail
security_module.description: Sendmail is a popular target of computer attackers. If this system is not intended to process incoming mail it is recommended that you disable the Sendmail daemon to avoid potential security vulnerabilities. Note that the following options are applicable to Linux only, and ignored for Solaris

option.name: requiredLines
option.helpText: List of required lines to put in /etc/sysconfig/sendmail if not already there (Linux only)

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Sendmail if older than 8.13.8
security_module.description: Disables the Sendmail service if the currently installed version isn't at least 8.13.8. When this module was written, prior versions of Sendmail had many vulnerabilties including WIZ and DECODE problems.

security_module.name: Disable Sendmail Help
security_module.description: Disables Sendmail help. This module removes the HelpFile option from sendmail.cf as well as emptying the /etc/mail/helpfile.

security_module.name: Configure Sendmail Options
security_module.description: Sets various Sendmail options to mask its version, enforce privacy (noexpn and novrfy), disable interactive help, ensure log level is at least nine, and prevent sendmail from finding and using $HOME/.forward files.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5
Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Log Critical Sendmail Messages
security_module.description: Logs critical-level Sendmail messages to /var/log/maillog.

security_module.name: Disable Accepting ICMP Redirects
security_module.description: Configures the system to refuse ICMP redirects. It is recommended that you apply this module to prevent denial-of-service attacks.

security_module.name: ARP Cleanup Interval
security_module.description: Set the length of time unsolicited requests remain in the ARP cache.

option.name: arpCleanupInterval
option.description: The length of time that unsolicited Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) requests remain in the ARP cache.

security_module.name: ARP IRE_CACHE Cleanup Interval
security_module.description: Set the interval, in milliseconds, in which IP Resolved Entries cache (IRE_CACHE) is scanned and entries are deleted that are more than one scan old. This interval is used for solicited arp entries, not unsolicited which are set with the "ARP Cleanup Interval" module.

option.name: arpCleanupIntervalIRE
option.description: The interval which the IRE_CACHE is scanned.

security_module.name: Disable Dhcpd
security_module.description: Disables Dynamic Host Control Protocol (DHCP) daemon.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Gated
security_module.description: Disables the gated service. This service manages routing protocols, but it is seldom deployed and is not part of the base operating system installation.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Innd
security_module.description: Disables the Internet Network News daemon (Innd).

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Broadcast Packet Forwarding
security_module.description: Disable Broadcast Packet Forwarding

security_module.name: Disable Network Analysis Tools
security_module.description: Disables network analysis tools by removing execution permissions. These include wireshark, tcpdump, and ethereal.

security_module.name: Disable Proxy Address Resolution Protocol (Proxy ARP)
security_module.description: Disable the Proxy Address Resolution Protocol (Proxy ARP). This prevents 'leakage' of address from one interface to other interfaces.

security_module.name: Disable Routed
security_module.description: Disables the routed service. This service dynamically updates the route table based on other machines on your network.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Ignore ICMP ECHO and TIMESTAMP Requests
security_module.description: Configures the system to disregard ICMP ECHO or TIMESTAMP requests that were sent to broadcast or multicast addresses. Ignoring these types of requests prevents your system from being part of a "smurf" attack.

security_module.name: Disable IP Forwarding
security_module.description: Disables IP forwarding. By default, your system is configured to forward IP packets for IPv4 network traffic. If your system is not being used as a router or gateway for other machines, then apply this module to your profile to disable IP forwarding.

security_module.name: Ignore Bogus ICMP4 Error Responses
security_module.description: Configures the system to ignore ICMP4 error responses This can reduce the size of log files.

security_module.name: Log Martian Packets
security_module.description: Log all packets showing up on an interface where they should not be seen. These can indicate either a spoofing attack or a misconfigured interface.

security_module.name: Enable Reverse Path Source Validation
security_module.description: Configures the system to perform source validation by reversed path. When you enable reverse path source validation, inbound packets are dropped if the IP address from where the packets were received is not reachable (i.e., asymmetrical route).

security_module.name: Disable Accepting Secure Redirects
security_module.description: Configures the system to block secure ICMP redirects. A secure redirect message is sent by a gateway that appears in the host's default gateway list. This message notifies the system that there is a shorter route to a particular destination. Spoofing a router's IP address is fairly simple; therefore, an attacker could use ICMP redirects in a potent denial-of-service attack if your system is configured to accept such redirects.

security_module.name: Disable Sending ICMP Redirects
security_module.description: Prohibits the system from sending ICMP redirects. The ICMP protocol uses "redirect" messages to notify a traffic source regarding its suboptimal use of routing. It is recommended that you apply this module to help prevent your system from being involved in denial-of-service attacks.

security_module.name: Set IP Strict Multihoming
security_module.description: Set IP Strict Multihoming

security_module.name: Disable Source Routing
security_module.description: Prevents the system from accepting network packets with routes predetermined by their source. By not accepting such packets, your system makes it difficult for an attacker to generate traffic that is pretending to be from inside your network.

security_module.name: SSH Disable GSSAPI Authentication
security_module.description: Configures the secure shell client to not accept GSSAPI authentication

security_module.name: SSH Parameters
security_module.description: Configures the secure shell (SSH) to only use protocol version 2 on outbound client connections by default. Version 1 of the SSH supported protocols contains security concerns and known vulnerabilities.

security_module.name: SSH Restrict Ciphers
security_module.description: Configures the secure shell (SSH) client to only use FIPS140-2 approved ciphers.

option.name: mustStartWith
option.helpText: Acceptable ciphers must start with one of the following entries. A leading '!' indicates that the cipher must not start with that text.

option.name: mustContain
option.helpText: Acceptable ciphers must contain one of the following entries. A leading '!' indicates that the cipher must not contain that text.

option.name: mustEndWith
option.helpText: Acceptable ciphers must end with one of the following entries. A leading '!' indicates that the cipher must not end with that text.

security_module.name: SSH Restrict HMAC
security_module.description: Configures the secure shell (SSH) client to only use the 'hmac-sha1' MAC algorithm.

security_module.name: SSHD Disable Empty Passwords
security_module.description: Configures the secure shell daemon to not allow logins for accounts with empty password strings.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: SSHD Disable GSSAPI Authentication
security_module.description: Configures the secure shell daemon to not accept GSSAPI authentication

security_module.name: SSHD Disable Host-based Authentication
security_module.description: Configures the secure shell daemon to not accept host-based authentication.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: SSHD Disable Kerberos Authentication
security_module.description: Configures the secure shell daemon to not accept Kerberos authentication

security_module.name: SSHD Disable Rhosts Authentication
security_module.description: Configures the secure shell daemon to not accept rhost-based authentication.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: SSHD Disable Rhosts RSA Authentication
security_module.description: Configures the secure shell daemon to not accept rhost-based authentication in concert with RSA authentication.

security_module.name: SSHD Disable Root Login
security_module.description: Configures the secure shell (SSH) daemon to refuse remote connections to the server made by logging directly into the root account.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: SSHD Enable Banner
security_module.description: Configures the secure shell daemon to display a banner from the file /etc/issue.net.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: SSHD Enable Ignore Rhosts
security_module.description: Configures the secure shell daemon to not accept rhosts files for login authentication.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: SSHD Enable X11 Forwarding
security_module.description: Configures the secure shell daemon to allow X11 sessions to be tunneled over the connection.

security_module.name: SSHD Permit User Environment
security_module.description: Configures the secure shell (SSH) daemon to prevent a user from altering the default environment settings.

security_module.name: SSHD Print Last Login by User
security_module.description: Configures the secure shell (SSH) daemon to show the last login by the user.

security_module.name: SSHD Protocol
security_module.description: Configures the secure shell daemon to not accept protocol 1 as an acceptable means of communication.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: SSHD Restrict Ciphers
security_module.description: Configures the secure shell (SSH) daemon to only use FIPS140-2 approved ciphers.

option.name: mustStartWith
option.helpText: Acceptable ciphers must start with one of the following entries. A leading '!' indicates that the cipher must not start with that text.

option.name: mustContain
option.helpText: Acceptable ciphers must contain one of the following entries. A leading '!' indicates that the cipher must not contain that text.

option.name: mustEndWith
option.helpText: Acceptable ciphers must end with one of the following entries. A leading '!' indicates that the cipher must not end with that text.

security_module.name: SSHD Restrict HMAC
security_module.description: Configures the secure shell (SSH) daemon to only use the 'hmac-sha1' MAC algorithm.

security_module.name: SSHD Restrict Users and Groups
security_module.description: Configures the secure shell (SSH) daemon to only accept logins from specific users and groups

security_module.name: SSHD Set Compression
security_module.description: Configures the secure shell daemon to disallow or delay compression

option.name: sshdCompressionMode
option.description: Compression setting for secure shell daemon (sshd)

security_module.name: SSHD Strict Mode Checking
security_module.description: Configures the secure shell daemon to require strict mode checking of home directory files

security_module.name: SSHD Use Privilege Separation
security_module.description: Configures the secure shell daemon to require privilege separation

security_module.name: Adjust Maximum Pending Connections
security_module.description: Configures the maximum number of SYN requests to keep in memory. These SYN requests are part of the TCP handshake process used to establish connections.

option.name: tcpMaxSynBacklog
option.description: Maximum number of remembered connection requests, which have not received an acknowledgment from connecting client.

security_module.name: Enable TCP Syncookies
security_module.description: Enables the system to send out requests (syncookies) to remote hosts if they are flooding your system's backlog queue with SYN packets. These requests check whether or not the inbound SYN packets are legitimate.

security_module.name: Enable Strong TCP Sequence Number Generation
security_module.description: Sets the mechanism for generating the order of TCP packets. For Solaris systems, this module sets the mechanism to use RFC 1948 sequence number generation, unique-per-connection-ID.

security_module.name: Enable TCP Wrappers
security_module.description: Verifies existence of, permissions, and required contents of the /etc/hosts.allow and /etc/hosts.deny files.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Lock expired account after inactivity
security_module.description: Controls the maximum number of days after a password expires that a local account becomes locked. This module does not change the current settings on active user accounts, just new accounts.

option.name: daysInactive
option.description: Number of days after password expires the account becomes locked.

security_module.name: No Empty Passwords
security_module.description: Prevents user accounts from having empty password fields. If a user account has an empty password field, then that account can be used to log in without entering a password.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: No Hashes Allowed in Passwd/Group Files
security_module.description: Detects hashed passwords in the passwd/group. Note that this is a scan only module - the system administrator will need to make any changes.

security_module.name: No Plus Entries in Password Files
security_module.description: Removes any "+" characters from local identification and authentication (IA) repositories: passwd, shadow, and group files. The "+" character is used to include Network Information Service (NIS) maps into local IA mechanisms. If you do not use NIS, then do not use the "+" character because it poses a security risk.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Minimum Delay Between Password Changes
security_module.description: Controls the minimum amount of time that must pass before users can change their passwords. This module does not change the current settings on active user accounts. The parameter this module sets applies to newly created local user accounts.

option.name: passwordMindays
option.description: Minimum number of days between password changes.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Maximum Time Between Password Changes
security_module.description: Controls the maximum allowed time period between password changes. This module does NOT change the current settings on existing, active user accounts. The parameter this module sets applies to newly created local user accounts.

option.name: passwordMaxdays
option.description: Maximum number of days between password changes.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Password Policy Consecutive Characters
security_module.description: Controls how many time a characters may be used consecutively in a user password.

option.name: passwordConsecutiveChars
option.description: Maximum consecutive repeats of the same characters.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Password Policy Different Characters
security_module.description: Controls how many different characters are required for new user password.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Password Policy Lowercase Minimum
security_module.description: Requires that new user-created passwords have at least one lowercase character.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Password Policy Length Minimum
security_module.description: Controls the minimum length of the user password.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Password Policy Numeric Minimum
security_module.description: Controls the minimum number of numeric characters in a user password. The default is at least 2 numeric characters, and this parameter cannot be changed.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Password Policy Special Characters
security_module.description: Controls the minimum number of special characters in a user password. The default is at least 2 special characters, and this parameter cannot be changed.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Password Policy Uppercase Minimum
security_module.description: Requires that passwords chosen by users have at least one uppercase character.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Limit Password Reuse
security_module.description: Limits the number of times a password can be reused. Requiring users to change passwords on a routine basis is only effective when the use of previous passwords is disallowed.

option.name: passwordReuse
option.description: Number of previous passwords which can not be reused.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Password Expiration Warning
security_module.description: Controls when users receive warnings of password expiration. You can set the number of days before password expiration when the user starts receiving warnings. Warnings are sent to the user starting on the date of the expiration warning. This module has an adjustable parameter. This module does not change the current settings on existing, active user accounts. The parameter this module sets applies to newly created local user accounts.

option.name: passwordExpireWarning
option.description: Number of days before password expires the system will notify the user.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Set Password Aging on Active Accounts
security_module.description: Sets all active accounts (except system accounts) to force password changes every MAX days, and then prevents password changes for MIN days thereafter. Users begin receiving warnings WARN days before their password expires. Once the password expires, the account is locked after INACT days.

option.name: passwordAgingMindays
option.description: Minimum number of days between password changes.

option.name: passwordAgingMaxdays
option.description: Maximum number of days between password changes.

option.name: passwordAgingExpireWarning
option.description: Number of days before password expires the system will notify the user.

option.name: passwordAgingInvalidate
option.description: Number of days to lock an account after its password has expired.

option.name: exemptSystemAccounts
option.helpText: Note - if system accounts are not exempt then they will be treated like user passwords and can expire, resulting in locked accounts.

option.name: exemptSpecificAccounts
option.helpText: This is a list of specific accounts (system or user accounts) that are exempt from the aging requirements. May require justification to any security accreditors.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: (PROFILE CUSTOMIZATION) - additions to exclude-dirs
security_module.description: This metamodule allows for Profile specific additions for the /var/lib/oslockdown/files/exclude-dirs file.

option.name: fileList
option.description: Additional directories to exclude (one per line)
option.helpText: This allows for Profile specific directories that OS Lockdown will exclude from processing. There should be one directory per line.

security_module.name: (PROFILE CUSTOMIZATION) - additions to inclusion-fstypes
security_module.description: This metamodule allows for Profile specific additions for the /var/lib/oslockdown/files/inclusion-fstypes file.

option.name: fileList
option.helpText: This allows for Profile specific filesystem types that OS Lockdown will include for processing. There should be one file system type per line.

security_module.name: (PROFILE CUSTOMIZATION) - additions to sgid_whitelist
security_module.description: This metamodule allows for Profile specific additions for the /var/lib/oslockdown/files/sgid_whitelist file.

option.name: fileList
option.helpText: This allows for Profile specific executables that are allowed to have the SGID bit set. There should be one executable per line.

security_module.name: (PROFILE CUSTOMIZATION) - additions to suid_whitelist
security_module.description: This metamodule allows for Profile specific additions for the /var/lib/oslockdown/files/suid_whitelist file.

option.name: fileList
option.helpText: This allows for Profile specific executables that are allowed to have the SUID bit set. There should be one executable per line.

security_module.name: Disable Console.perms
security_module.description: Disables the /etc/security/console.perms file by renaming the file to /etc/security/console.perms.disabled

security_module.name: Disable PAM Console Library
security_module.description: Disables PAM from granting sole access to administrative privileges to the first user who logs into the console. The PAM Console library gives users (at the physical console) capabilities that they would not otherwise have, and removes those capabilities when the users are no longer logged in at the console. It provides two main kinds of capabilities: file permissions and authentication.

security_module.name: Limit Access To Root From Su
security_module.description: Restricts root account access to users who belong to the wheel group. This prevents users outside of the wheel group from using the su(1) command to access the root account, even with the root password.

option.name: requireNonRootWheelMember
option.description: Require at least 1 non-root user in the wheel group? If 'no' this module can prevent anyone from using the 'su' command.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Lock Non-Root Accounts with UID 0
security_module.description: Locks any account that has a user identification (UID) of zero that is also not the root user. Only the root user should have this unique UID. A user with the same UID will have the same privileges as root.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Remove Insecure_Locks option for NFS Server
security_module.description: Searches for exported filesystems that have the "insecure_locks" option set in the configuration file and removes the option.

security_module.name: Secure Option for NFS Server
security_module.description: This module searches for NFS-exported filesystems that have the "insecure" option set in the configuration file, and replaces the option with "secure".

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Deny NFS Client Access Without UID or GID
security_module.description: Denies NFS client access without UID or GID by setting the NFS export options to change the UID and GID of the anonymous account to "nfsnobody"

security_module.name: Allowed shells in /etc/shells
security_module.description: Sets the approved list of system shells. Users are only allowed to change their login shell to a shell on this list, which prevents an unauthorized program from being used as a login shell.

option.name: allowedShells
option.description: Explicitly allowed shells for user accounts. The order is not important. The default list is empty as they vary from OS to OS, so please refer to the shells man page or your vendor OS documentation to obtain the correct default list.

security_module.name: Root Console Only Logins
security_module.description: Prevents direct login access to the root account (except in single-user mode). This ensures that personnel using the account have physical access to the machine or have permission to use the switch user command (su(1)) to the account. Utilizing su(1) as the vehicle to gain access to the root account provides an additional measure of accountability through auditing.

option.name: secureDevices
option.helpText: Devices where direct root login will be allowed (i.e., console, tty1)

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Root Home Directory Permissions
security_module.description: Restricts access to the root home directory to only those users with root privileges. This module expects the root home directory is something other than '/', otherwise it will fail and no changes will be made.

security_module.name: Root Path
security_module.description: Including the current working directory ('.') or other writable directory in the root executable path allows an attacker to gain superuser status by forcing an administrator operating as root to execute a Trojan horse program. This module will only report on PATH problems because it is unable to remove the current working directory ('.') from the root path because there are too many variables involved in locating where this insertion takes place.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5
Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Root shell must be on / filesystem
security_module.description: Changes the root account's shell to the default /bin/bash if the current shell does not reside on the / filesystem. On Solaris systems, this module will set the shell to /sbin/sh if the module fails.

security_module.name: Single User Mode Password
security_module.description: This module modifies the system to require password authentication prior to allowing root access from within single user mode.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: At/Cron Access File Permissions
security_module.description: This module restricts access to the At/Cron access files (*.allow, *.deny), preventing unauthorized access/modification.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: At Directory Permissions
security_module.description: This module restricts access to the 'at' spool directory to approved users, preventing unauthorized access/modification.

security_module.name: Secure Audio Devices
security_module.description: Restricts access to the audio device (/dev/audio*) files.

security_module.name: Audit tool permissions
security_module.description: Restrict permissions on Audit tools

security_module.name: Bind Mount /var/tmp to /tmp
security_module.description: Ensure that /tmp is also mounted as /var/tmp with restrictive options

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Boot Loader Configuration File Permissions
security_module.description: This module prevents non-root users from editting the boot loader configuration files, preventing unauthorized access/modification.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Configure Permissions on /usr/bin/ldd
security_module.description: Configure allowed permissions on the /usr/bin/ldd command for Linux. Note that if the permissions are too restrictive this can impact third-party software such as VMware tools

security_module.name: Consult the RPM Database for file/directory setting
security_module.description: Use the data within the RPM database to verify permissions on files and directories.

option.name: honorChangesBySB
option.description: Should files owned by root/root with permissions of 000 be left alone?
option.helpText: If OS Lockdown needs to remove a file or entry (for example, if an unowned file is found) the ownership it set to root:root, and the permissions are set to 000. This module would undo every single one of those changes unless told to allow those changes to persist.

option.name: packageExemptions
option.description: List of RPM packages to ignore

option.name: fileExemptions
option.description: List of specific files/dirs to ignore (dirs are treated non-recursively), one entry per line

security_module.name: Correct Uneven File Permissions
security_module.description: Ensures files and directories do not have uneven file permissions. This means that the group must not have more permissions than the owner. If the permissions are uneven, this module will set the permissions to 0755.

security_module.name: Crontab Dir Perms
security_module.description: Restricts the permissions/owner of the crontab directories.

security_module.name: Crontab Perms
security_module.description: Restricts the permissions on the crontab spool/configuration files.

option.name: userSpoolDirs
option.description: Location of crontab spool directories and configuration file

option.name: userCanOwn
option.description: Allow users ownership (w/primary group) of personal crontab file?

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Crontab Script Perms
security_module.description: Restricts the permissions/owners of the crontab script files.

option.name: crontabScriptDirs
option.description: Location of system crontab script directories

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: NFS Export Configuration File Permissions
security_module.description: This module restricts access to the NFS exports configuration file, preventing unauthorized access/modification.

security_module.name: FTP Configuration File Permissions
security_module.description: This module prevents non-root users from editting the FTP configuration files, preventing unauthorized access/modification.

security_module.name: Global Initialization File Permissions
security_module.description: This module prevents non-root users from editting the global initialization files, preventing unauthorized access/modification.

security_module.name: Hosts File Permissions
security_module.description: This module prevents non-root users from editting the /etc/hosts file, preventing unauthorized access/modification.

security_module.name: Inetd/Xinetd Configuration File Permissions
security_module.description: This module prevents non-root users from editting the inetd/xinetd configuration files, preventing unauthorized access/modification.

security_module.name: Kernel Core Dump Directory Permissions
security_module.description: This module prevents non-root users from accessing the kernel core dump directory/files, preventing unauthorized access/modification.

security_module.name: LDAP Configuration File Permissions
security_module.description: This module restricts access to the LDAP configuration file, preventing unauthorized access/modification.

security_module.name: Management Information Base (MIB) File Permissions
security_module.description: This module restricts access to Management Information Base (MIB) files, preventing unauthorized access/modification.

security_module.name: Mail Agent Aliases Files Permissions
security_module.description: This module restricts access to the Mail agent aliases files, preventing unauthorized access/modification.

option.name: allowedGnamesAliasesDB
option.description: Allowed Group Name(s) specifically for aliases.db
option.helpText: Overrides the allowed groupname for filename 'aliases.db', as required by sendmail. This is normally the 'smmsp' group.

security_module.name: Restrict Write-Access on Man Pages
security_module.description: Set permissions on manual pages in /usr/share/man, /usr/share/info, and /usr/share/infopage to allow only root to modify them.

security_module.name: NTP file permissions
security_module.description: Restrict permissions for NTP configuration files

security_module.name: NIS/NIS+/YP Configuration File Permissions
security_module.description: This module restricts access to the NIS/NIS+/YP configurations files, preventing unauthorized access/modification.

security_module.name: InterNetNews Config File Perms
security_module.description: Restricts access to the InterNetNews (INN) configuration files.

security_module.name: Name Service Switch Configuration File Permissions
security_module.description: This module prevents non-root users from editting the /etc/nsswitch.conf file, preventing unauthorized access/modification.

security_module.name: Password Perms
security_module.description: Secures password files with permissions that protect them from being directly modified by unauthorized users.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Printer Configuration File Permissions
security_module.description: This module restricts access to the printer configuration files, preventing unauthorized access/modification.

security_module.name: Resolver Configuration File Permissions
security_module.description: This module prevents non-root users from editting the /etc/resolv.conf file, preventing unauthorized access/modification.

security_module.name: Restrict Use of Compiler Tools
security_module.description: Restricts the use of compiler tools such as gcc and g++ to the superuser (root).

security_module.name: Restrict Use of Traceroute and Ping
security_module.description: Restricts the use of the traceroute(8) and ping(8) commands to the superuser (root).

security_module.name: SELinux Find unlabeled_t files
security_module.description: Examine the filesystem looking for any files with the 'unlabeled_t' SELinux context. If SELinix is unsupported or disabled, this Module will always pass. Note that this Module is a 'scan-only' Module, any findings required manual action to remediate.

option.name: checkWhichFiles
option.helpText: Should only files in /dev or all files be checked?

security_module.name: SNMP Configuration File Permissions
security_module.description: This module prevents non-root users from editting the SNMP daemon configuration files, preventing unauthorized access/modification.

security_module.name: Samba Configuration File Permissions
security_module.description: This module restricts access to the Samba configuration file, preventing unauthorized access/modification.

security_module.name: Samba Password File Permissions
security_module.description: This module restricts access to the Samba password files, preventing unauthorized access/modification.

security_module.name: Secure SUID/SGID Executables
security_module.description:
Searches for unauthorized set-ID programs and removes their set-ID permissions. Set-UID and set-GID programs can be compromised and used to violate system integrity.
Administrators can edit the files in the directory /var/lib/oslockdown/files/ to add additional set-ID programs to the list of authorized set-ID files. Any set-ID file on the system that does not appear in one of these files is considered to be unauthorized.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Secure Unowned Files
security_module.description: Removes unowned status on files. Normally, file system objects should have named user and group ownership. This could be from deleted applications or accounts. It could also be from an import of data from another system or an intruder.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Secure World Writable Devices
security_module.description: Removes world-writable permission on device files. Normally, any user on the system can alter data on a world-writable device. World-writable permission could lead to a larger compromise of the system's integrity.

option.name: specialDevices
option.description: List of specific device files that should *always* be owned by root, with permissions 666 (read/write by anyone)

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Secure World Writable Directories
security_module.description: Secures World Writable Directories by setting the "sticky" bit on a directory that restricts file removal to the file owner. Without the "sticky" bit, any user can remove any file in this directory. This setting is common practice for most shared directories such as /tmp and /var/tmp.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Secure World Writable Files
security_module.description: Removes world-writable permission on files. Normally, any user on the system can alter data in world-writable files. If the file is a program, world-writable permission could lead to a larger compromise of the system's integrity.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Access.conf File Permissions
security_module.description: This module restricts access to the /etc/security/access.conf access file, preventing unauthorized access/modification.

security_module.name: Services File Permissions
security_module.description: This module prevents non-root users from editting the /etc/service file, preventing unauthorized access/modification.

security_module.name: Shadow Perms
security_module.description: Restrict permissions to the password shadow files in /etc to root (or passwd if SUSE)

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Secure Shell Binaries
security_module.description: Sets file permissions on shell binaries assigned to user accounts to only allow root to write to them. This prevents unauthorized modifications to shell binaries such as /bin/bash or /bin/ksh.

security_module.name: Skeleton File Permissions
security_module.description: Set permissions on user account skeleton files so all new accounts are created initially with a known configuration.

security_module.name: System Command File Permissions
security_module.description: Controls access to key system commands. Most system commands can only be used by root which checks required access upon execution. This module prevents non-root users from executing the command by removing the world-execution bit.

security_module.name: System Configuration File Permissions
security_module.description: Controls access to key system configuration files and directories.

security_module.name: System Device Directory Ownership
security_module.description: Controls access to key system device directories. System device directories under /dev should be owned by root and group root. This module ensures that these subdirectories have root set as the owner and group.

security_module.name: System Library File Permissions
security_module.description: Controls access to key system libraries. System libraries in /usr/lib should be 0755 and owned by root. This module ensures that the libraries are set to 0755.

security_module.name: System Log File Permissions
security_module.description: Controls system log files in /var/log so they have file permissions that prevent world read access and in some cases even group access. Proper file ownership is also established.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: System Logging Configuration File Permissions
security_module.description: This module prevents non-root users from editting the files controlling how the system logger is configured, preventing unauthorized access/modification.

security_module.name: System Run Control Script Permissions
security_module.description: Restricts access to the system run control scripts. System run control scripts are responsible for starting and stopping services as the machine boots or shuts down.

security_module.name: Sysctl.conf Permissions
security_module.description: Secures configuration file permissions so that non-privileged users cannot modify sysctl.conf(5). Parameters for the kernel are stored in this file. This file should be owned by the root user, belong to the root group, and be readable and writable only by the root user.

security_module.name: Verify required software cryptographic certs are installed
security_module.description: Verify required software cryptographic signatures are installed.

option.name: requiredCerts
option.helpText: A line of required certificate values (one per line)

option.name: showExtraCerts
option.description: Should any certificates found other than the above be shown?
option.helpText: Display any additional certificates found on the system that aren't in the required list. May help detect if a person is attempting to install malicious software...

security_module.name: Disable SNMP if default public string exists
security_module.description: Disables the SNMP agent if the default community 'public' has not been changed.

security_module.name: Configure /etc/audit/auditd.conf Settings
security_module.description: Ensure required settings are present in /etc/audit/auditd.conf

option.name: auditConfs
option.description: List of setting (one per line, "NAME VALUE")

security_module.name: Configure /etc/ldap.conf Settings
security_module.description: Ensure required settings are present in /etc/ldap.conf

option.name: ldapConfs
option.description: List of setting (one per line, "NAME VALUE")

security_module.name: Configure Xinetd Logging
security_module.description: Ensures required logging lines are enabled for all xinetd services. Note that the options below are only for Linux, and that this module may overwrite custom settings for files in /etc/xinetd.d directory. Solaris does not require user options.

option.name: addToSubFilesIfMissing
option.description: Add to all /etc/xinetd.d/* files if missing?

security_module.name: Correct Global Init Script PATH Variables
security_module.description: Strip single periods or double colons from PATH environment variables set in global initilization files such as /etc/profile.

security_module.name: Correct System RC Script PATH Variables
security_module.description: Removes single periods or double colons from PATH environment variables set in system run control scripts (/etc/init.d/*).

security_module.name: Daemon Umask
security_module.description: Configures system services to create files that only the user can modify and group members can read. Setting the system's default umask to 027 restricts newly created file and directory access to their respective owners and groups. This setting reduces the likelihood of other services or users overwriting or reading data owned by another process.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Abrtd
security_module.description: The abrtd daemon is used to generate information about processes that have crashed, and can expose sensitive information about the system.

security_module.name: Disable ACPI Daemon
security_module.description: Disable the Advanced Configuration and Power Interface (acpid) daemon.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Power Management
security_module.description: Disables the power management service.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable atd Service
security_module.description: Disable the 'at' daemon which queues jobs for later execution. Many of the periodic or delayed execution features of the 'at' daemon can be provided through the 'cron' daemon instead so disable the 'at' daemon if possible.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Autofs Daemon
security_module.description: Disables the Autofs daemon that is used to automatically mount local media and/or remote network shares

security_module.name: Disable Avahi Daemon
security_module.description: Disables the Avahi daemon. The Avahi daemon facilitates automated service discovery on a local network.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Bluetooth
security_module.description: Disables Bluetooth services. The Bluetooth services may allow unauthorized communications with the server if not properly configured.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Bluetooth Input Devices Daemon
security_module.description: Disable Bluetooth Input Devices daemon. If the system has no Bluetooth input devices (e.g., wireless keyboard or mouse) disable this daemon.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Boot Caching
security_module.description: Disables the readahead_early and readahead_later services on Red Hat systems. These services provide one-time caching of files belonging to some boot services, with the goal of allowing the system to boot faster.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable CDE Calendar Manager Server
security_module.description: Disables network access to the Solaris CDE Calendar Manager.

security_module.name: Disable CPU Throttling
security_module.description: Disables the cpuspeed daemon which uses hardware support to throttle the CPU when the system is idle. If CPU power optimization is necessary, don't use this module.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable DNS
security_module.description: Disables the Domain Name System (DNS), which is used to translate numerical IP addresses into human-readable machine names.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Finger
security_module.description: Disables the Finger service. If left enabled, this service can be used by remote systems to obtain information about users.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Firstboot Service
security_module.description: Firstboot is a daemon specific to the Red Hat installation process. It handles "one-time" configuration following successful installation of the operating system. As such, there is no reason for this service to remain enable.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Console Mouse Support
security_module.description: Disables the GPM service that is used to provide console-based mouse support.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable GSS Daemon
security_module.description: Disables Generic Security Service (GSS) daemon.

security_module.name: Disable Graphical Login
security_module.description: Disables the graphical login manager by changing the system's default run-level from 5 to 3 in /etc/inittab. When the machine is rebooted, a text login will be provided instead of a graphical one.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable HP Printing and Imaging
security_module.description: Disables HP printing and imaging. The hplip service is used to support HP printing and imaging services.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable HAL Daemon
security_module.description: Disables the Hardware Abstraction Layer (HAL) daemon (haldaemon). The haldaemon provides a dynamic way of managing device interfaces. It automates device configuration and provides an API for making devices accessible to applications through the D-Bus interface. Since HAL provides valuable attack surfaces to attackers as an intermediary to privileged operations, it should be disabled unless necessary.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable IA32 Microcode Utility
security_module.description: Disables the IA32 Microcode utility. This module will prevent the utility from running during system startup. The utility is for use with Intel IA32 processors (Pentium Pro, PII, Celeron, PIII, Xeon, Pentium 4, etc.).

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable ISDN
security_module.description: Disables the ISDN service that is used to support ISDN network configurations.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Inetd
security_module.description: Disables Inetd, which is the Internet super-server daemon. It spawns a number of other servers, such as telnet and ftp.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable IRDA Service
security_module.description: Disable the Infrared Data Association (IrDA) service.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable IRQ Balance Service
security_module.description: In a Red Hat server environment with multiple processors, the IRQ Balance service is useful and should be left enabled. However, if a machine has only one processor, the service should be disabled. This module will not disable the service if there is more than one processor.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Kernel Crash Analyzer
security_module.description: Disables the kernel crash dump analyzer (kdump), which uses the kexec to boot a secondary kernel following a system crash.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Kerberos TGT Expiration Warning
security_module.description: Disables the Solaris Kerberos warning daemon (ktkt_warnd(1M)). When this daemon is enabled on Kerberos clients it can warn users when their Kerberos tickets are about to expire, or renew the tickets before they expire.

security_module.name: Disable Kudzu
security_module.description: On Red Hat systems, Kudzu is the hardware configuration daemon. The daemon allows anyone with console access to reconfigure the system's hardware without authentication.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable LDAP Client Cache Manager
security_module.description: Disables the Solaris LDAP client cache manager (ldap_cachemgr(1M)) daemon; which manages client configuration for LDAP based Network Information Service lookups.

security_module.name: Disable MCS Translation Service
security_module.description: Disable the SELinux Translation Service daemon. Category labelling is unlikely to be used except in sites with special requirements. Therefore, it should be disabled in order to reduce the amount of potentially vulnerable code running on the system.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Software RAID Monitor
security_module.description: Disable the Software RAID Monitor (mdmonitor) service. This service is extraneous unless software RAID is in use.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable NIS Client
security_module.description: Disables the Network Information Service (NIS) client. The NIS is a system that provides network information such as login names and home directories to all the machines on a network.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable NIS Server
security_module.description: Disables the Network Information Service (NIS) server. The NIS is a system that provides network information such as login names and home directories to all the machines on a network.

security_module.name: Disable Netconsole
security_module.description: Unless there is a need to debug kernel panics, it is recommended that this service be disabled.

security_module.name: Disable Ntpdate
security_module.description: The 'ntpdate' daemon is used to configure system time when a box reboots. This functionality is present in the 'ntpd' service, and therefore should not be used.

security_module.name: Disable Oddjobd
security_module.description: The oddjob daemon provides some additional ability to execute actions via the D-Bus interface, but it is recommended that the service be disabled unless required.

security_module.name: Disable Portmap Daemon
security_module.description: Disables the Portmap daemon that is used to convert RPC program numbers into DARPA protocol port numbers. RPC is an unencrypted protocol that may carry authentication information.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Prelinking
security_module.description: Disable '/usr/sbin/prelink' from prelinking current system binaries for faster startup.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5
Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Printer Daemon
security_module.description: Disables the Common UNIX Printing System (CUPS). When enabled, this service may allow unauthorized remote systems to send print jobs to a system that is not properly configured.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Printer Configuration Daemon
security_module.description: Disables the CUPS printer configuration daemon that is used to configure the CUPS subsystem.

security_module.name: Disable Qpidd
security_module.description: The qpidd service is used to listen for Advanced Message Queing Protocol (AMQP) traffic. It is recommended that the service be disabled unless required.

security_module.name: Disable Raw Devices Service
security_module.description: Disable the Raw Devices service, which assigns raw devices to block devices and is commonly used by database systems.

line-item.name: Guide to the Secure Configuration of RHEL5

security_module.name: Disable Rdisc
security_module.description: The rdisc daemon is used with the ICMP Router Discovery Protocol (IRDP)to assist with network discovery and setup.It is recommended that the service be disabled.

security_module.name: Disable Remote Syslog
